I had this issue too. I did some reading online and decided to take a break and visit the chiropractor. 3-4 weeks laterI was back in the gym.
My chiropractor described the issue to me. He said one of the cervical vertebra was pinching the main nerve going up the neck and across the top of the head. He said it can be caused by my form.
A lot of people tend to keep stress in there head and hold there breath. This is bad. I find that when I contract my abdominals and stare blankly at an unmoving object in front of me, the tension in my neck/head dissipates.

Yes they are, but what compels us to comment in this thread? What provokes us to judge these women we have never met in our lives? Lets not worry about the issues of the runway models, starving children in Africa, or junkies in Europe. We need to address our own issues before we can be completely morally obligated to the problems of others. We use the problems of others as an outlet for ourselves so often that we forget that we are struggling ourselves.
Before someone gets upset over what I just said, I was using some rhetoric to bring home an idea. We can obviously multitask and help out those in need while helping ourselves. But don't use charity to run away from your own issues.

I live in southern Colorado a rock throw away from the Southern Ute. It's amazing to see how they have integrated and rose above the non-natives after they were transplanted from Utah. I was devastated after driving through and hiking around your reservation. The shear contrast in between the two neighboring tribes is mind boggling. Your culture awe inspiring, but seeing homes without electricity or running water is depressing.
Is there anything we can do to get you back on your feet?
**EDIT** Since what I said appears to be unpopular, allow me to expand upon my interests and attitudes. I am compelled by and genuinely love Native American culture. I'm not a white knight or going for Internet points. I don't want to see the Natives die in eastern tradition.

Exercise helps me in a few places, but therapy has really helped me as a whole. Working out can be a great stepping stone though. It's easy to set an objective fitness goal and force yourself to do it. You are then rewarded with more energy and confidence.
For me, depression stemmed from my anxiety. My manorexia then stemmed from depression. The depression and eating disorder fell into place pretty quickly and it became a part of me. I went from that anxious kid to the skinny sad anxious kid in the matter of weeks. My friends accepted it and so did I.
So I graduated High School early, moved across the country, and went inpatient for the eating disorder. That big and sudden change (I decided to do all this about two weeks before I was on the plane) was half the battle for me. I was now in a position where I could be a different person. This is just an observation but, the less depressed I am the less I identify as that depressed kid.
Being almost a year after I made my big change I can definitely say I am not depressed. I do have my lows, but I think much less about suicide, restricting my food, or sleeping.
Beyond the big change in environment, therapy has guided helped guide me. My therapist is great at challenging me. I think everyone can benefit from therapy as long as they are truly willing to be open.
Tl;dr I changed my environment and therapy helps.

I think language is a synthetic science a priori. So it differs from physical sciences in that respect. I was just building on your comment with what insight I have.

So the issue is language?
Objective statements are always relative to something (axioms, objects, events, etc.). We just don't admit this relative objective reality in language because of contexts.
When someone says "I need water", the observer can infer the objective goal of the statement based on contexts. So that statement may actually read "I need water to quench my thirst". Wouldn't the context support our desire to remain in the same location when we travel through time?
The question in the title is rhetorical.
*what follows is the remainder of my comment that was written some time after the preceding part.*
I get the idea that the OP was just being clever with this thread. It is interesting none the less, but we rarely think about the transcendent idea in a statement. We are always so quick to dismiss the idea's hidden contexts, yet we rely so heavily on the hidden contexts. Imagine if de facto was concerned only with the tangible grammar. For me it's fun to think about such things. We communicate in very complex (or as I like to say, dynamic ) forms.

Do you want to die? Or do you not like where you are (mentally, physically, and emotionally)?
Honestly, no one cares what mental disorders you have or your history. I have my fair share of issues and I identified with my issues too much. I was thinking way too much about my issues and it showed. I never made any attempts, but fantasized about suicide. I thought about how nice it would be to not be anymore. I don't know what changed for me, but I stopped surrounding myself with negative thoughts. I stopped identifying with my issues. With this sudden shift, I slowly stopped fantasizing about death.
I'm not telling you to do anything or giving you answers. It's just my anecdote. I still have my issues, but they have a lesser effect on me. I walk with my issues
I hope you find whatever you're looking for.
P.S. If you haven't already, consider therapy. My therapist has helped me more than anyone on my road to recovery than anyone/thing. The unexamined life is not worth living.

I'm not sure what breed we have. They are dirty blonde and good in cold climates. We chose them for there ability to live in cold climates. I'm living down here in Pagosa Springs and it gets cold (twenty below this morning). And, Yes we use the hay bales for insulation (though the chickens think they are for jumping off of :P).
Heat lamps are the way to go. You still need to be careful though

We have 26 chickens! 24 hens and two roosters. We ordered our through a catalog and they were shipped to use (I'm not pulling you leg). Do some research online for breeds and buying supplies.
We had been switching every week with our neighbor's chickens for a year until we decided to get our own little fluff balls this October. They arrived about a day after they hatched and we kept them inside for 6~ weeks.
I recommend keeping them inside and interacting with them on a daily basis. Chickens are pretty stupid animals, but they you can train them. We put them out in our barn when they grew enough feathers to tolerate ~45*F.
We have three heat lamps set up on a timer and they seem happy. When you convert your shed remember this, **INSULATION**. Keeping the hot air in can keep the temperature from fluctuating too much (chickens don't like that) and gives you peace of mind. We use hay bales on the inside perimeter of the coop and hay on the floors. We are thinking of ways to insulate the roof, but we have the wiring for the heat lamps on the roof (i.e. avoiding fire hazards).
All in all, chickens are chalked full of character and super easy to own. For specific information on backyard chickens do some research on the internet and go to the book store.

He never begged the question. He raised the question. Let's put my pet peeve aside and raise some questions of our own. What can we do now that will make it difficult for the federal government to intervene? If the government intervenes, what can we do to push our ideas forward?
Obama is not working for his reelection anymore, so I think we should find a way to support Obama in making the choice that is conducive to legalizing cannabis. I do not know how we can do this, but we should look at Obama's personal interests. Does he want to strengthen relationships with the Justice Department? Democratic Party? his dog? Are his interests financial?
You get the idea. Put yourself in his shoes to understand his actions.

Try body weight exercises in the morning before you go skiing. Pull ups, push ups, dips, and any variations of each. Lightly stretch and go shred. If you are concerned about losing weight than of course try and eat more. It's best to tell yourself now that you will lose some weight. Even if you don't lose weight, just keep saying that. Do your best and don't worry about it. You're going on an awesome trip and you're gonna have a blast. Some things just aren't worth and stressing over a few pounds is definitely not worth it.
Oh yeah, be safe. An injury will certainly not help you retain your muscle or have fun.
One more thing, there was a thread on newschoolers a few days ago about weight training and skiing. It turned into a shit storm like most threads there, but you might get some inspiration.
/r/funny gives me a good laugh every so often. I have nothing against funny (besides the occasional repost)
